messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 69 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On Counting Propositional LogicThis work has been partially supported by the ErC CoG ‚ÄúDIAPASoN‚Äù, GA 818616.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study counting propositional logic as an extension of propositional logic with counting quantifiers. We prove that the complexity of the underlying decision problem perfectly matches the appropriate level of Wagner‚Äôs counting hierarchy, but also that the resulting logic admits a satisfactory proof theoretical treatment. From the latter, a type system for a probabilistic ŒªùúÜ\lambda-calculus is derived in the spirit of the Curry-Howard correspondence, showing the potential of counting propositional logic as a useful tool in several fields of theoretical computer science.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 69 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 69"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Counting hierarchies: Polynomial time and constant depth circuits",
        "On measure quantifiers in first-order arithmetic (long version)",
        "Type-based complexity analysis of probabilistic functional programs",
        "Lp, a logic for representing and reasoning with statistical knowledge",
        "On probability distributions over possible worlds",
        "Probabilistic belief logics",
        "Representing and Reasoning with Probabilistic Knowledge",
        "Probability and Measure",
        "Probabilistic rewrite strategies. applications to elan",
        "On intersection types and probabilisitic lambda calculi",
        "Theory of quantified boolean formulas",
        "Reduced forms for stochastic sequential machines",
        "The complexity of theorem-proving procedures",
        "Probabilistic termination by monadic affine sized typing",
        "Decomposing probabilistic lambda-calculi",
        "Probabilistic operational semantics for the lambda calculus",
        "Markov chains as random input automata",
        "Computability by probabilistic machines",
        "Probabilistic lambda-caclulus and quantitative program analysis",
        "The computational meaning of probabilistic coherence spaces",
        "Uncertainty, belief, and probability",
        "Reasoning about knowledge and probability",
        "A logic for reasoning about probabilities",
        "Probabilistic logics based on Riesz spaces",
        "Computational complexity of probabilistic turing machines",
        "Proof and Types",
        "Uniform labelled calculi for conditional and counterfactual logics",
        "An analysis of first-order logics for probability",
        "Reasoning About Uncertainty",
        "A logic for reasoning about time and reliability",
        "Effective bayesian inference for stochastic programs",
        "A logical characterization of the counting hierarchy",
        "Semantics of probabilistic programs",
        "Reasoning with time and chance",
        "A deterministic rewrite system for the probabilistic ?-calculus",
        "The equivalence problem for regular expressions with squaring requires exponential space",
        "Word problems requiring exponential time (preliminary report)",
        "Proof Analysis: A Contribution to Hilbert‚Äôs Last Problem",
        "Probabilistic logic",
        "Probabilistic logic revisited",
        "On bunched typing",
        "Games against nature",
        "Parallel computation with threshold functions",
        "A calculus for probabilistic languages",
        "A probabilistic language based upon sampling functions",
        "Toward general analysis of recursive probability modesl",
        "Markov Decision Processes: Discrete Stochastic Dynamic Programming",
        "Probabilistic automata",
        "Stochastic lambda calculus and monads of probability distributions",
        "Probabilistic LCF",
        "Maximin automata",
        "Maximin sequential-like machines and chains",
        "Probabilistic Turing machines and computability",
        "Computability by probabilistic Turing machines",
        "On tape-bounded probabilistic Turing machine acceptors",
        "Lectures on the Curry-Howard Isomorphism, volume 149",
        "The polynomial-time hiearchy",
        "On the computational power of pp and ‚ôØ‚ôØ\\sharpp",
        "PP is as hard as the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "An oracle characterization of the counting hierarchy",
        "Complexity classes defined by counting quantifiers",
        "The complexity of computing the permanent",
        "Is there a use for linear logic?",
        "Compact descriptions and the counting polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "The complexity of combinatorial problems with succinct input representation",
        "Some observations on the connection between counting and recursion",
        "Complete sets and the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "Probabilistic quantifiers and games",
        "A decisive characterization of BPP"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 69 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On Counting Propositional LogicThis work has been partially supported by the ErC CoG ‚ÄúDIAPASoN‚Äù, GA 818616., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
